choices: Attend the festival
By partaking in the vote, you did the right thing. While citizens were not absolutely required to vote in the Assembly, it was considered a civic duty and voting was very encouraged.
Search for a male relative first

This was an expectation of women in ancient Athens. They had to have a male companion when leaving property (Source: ThoughtCo). Being caught without a male companion could lead to shame, though it is not a strict law. Therefore, you can leave of your own free will.

text: A man visits while your husband is away.
choices: Let him come in, then send him off
Even if nothing much happens, rumors could spread. In Athens, even a short interaction with unrelated men could bring shame or divorce.
Ask a servant to speak
You protect your honor. Athenian women were expected to avoid private contact with unrelated men. Even a short interaction could lead to divorce.

text: Your father is arranging a marriage.
choices: Grudgingly accept

You decide there is no point in arguing, as your father has the most control over your marriage. According to Wikipedia and confirmed by Cedarbank School, it was a social obligation for fathers to choose their daughter's marriage.
Argue about it

Your father sees your behavior as disobedient. In Athens, a woman's duty was to obey her father, and defiance, especially publicly, was dangerous to a family's reputation. According to Wikipedia and confirmed by Cedarbank School, it was a social obligation for fathers to choose their daughter's marriage.

text: You catch your servant stealing food.
choices: Talk to him privately
Though this is the more humane approach, women could indeed beat their servants. A more harsh punishment for your servant could do a better job of preventing this from happening again.
Scold/beat him

Surprisingly, Athenian women could physically harm their servants. Cedarbank School writes that women were fully in charge of their slaves. A more harsh punishment for the servant could do a better job for preventing this from happening again.

choices: Eagerly accept
